channel.title: The Moscow Times - News, Business, Culture & Multimedia from Russia
channel.description: The Moscow Times offers everything you need to know about Russia: Breaking news, top stories, business, analysis, opinion, multimedia, upcoming cultural events

item.title: American Unintelligence on Russia (Op-ed)
item.description: Americaâ€™s case against the Kremlin suffers from major flaws that should be acknowledged, even by those who argue that Russia hacked U.S. democratic institutions, says Kevin Rothrock.

item.title: Bend Your Body, Break the Law
item.description: Yoga in Russia is back under fire, as an instructor in St. Petersburg heads to trial for delivering a lecture that police say amounts to â€œillegal missionary work.â€

item.title: Russia, the Inequality Champion (Op-ed)
item.description: Nowhere else in the developed world are incomes so unevenly skewed in favour of the richest, says Boris Grozovsky

item.title: Russian Army Publishes Pictures of Aleppo Ruins
item.description: Haunting images little doubt as to the hellish nature of existence during the final days inside this anti-Assad enclave.

item.title: Highlights of 2016 in The Moscow Times
item.description: Hacking. Doping. Putin. Bulldozers. Sechin. Arrests. Brexit. Sham privatization. More arrests. An election in Russia that nobody noticed. Another Russian election everyone noticed. 2016 was a remarkable year for Russia and the relaunched Moscow Times.

item.title: Russia's Graceless Goodbye to America's First Black President
item.description: Whatever you think of Putinâ€™s apparent magnanimity on Friday, thereâ€™s no debate that prominent figures in Russian society have been far less restrained in their comments this week about Barack Obama.

item.title: The Year That Putin Won
item.description: The year 2016 looked decidedly more promising for Russia and its rulers than 2014. Domestically, no serious challenge arose to the current social and political order. Internationally, Russia is no longer the kind of pariah it was in 2014 and 2015.

item.title: How Russia Became a Hacking Superpower
item.description: Moscow has finally got the geopolitical respect it demanded for years, but only after spooking Washington.

item.title: The New Axis: Russia, Turkey and Iran Take Over Syria
item.description: This is Putinâ€™s personal revenge on Obama for having labeled Russia a â€œdecliningâ€ and â€œregionalâ€ power. With the Russia-Turkey-Iran axis, it is the U.S. that is the declining power on the Middle East.

item.title: The Great Break: Moscow on Vacation
item.description: While many expats go back to their home countries for the long holiday break, for those who stay Moscow is a vacationerâ€™s paradise.

item.title: In a Spin: Kremlin Wrestles With Russia's Revolutionary History
item.description: On the eve of the 1917 revolution's centennial, fact gives way to myth as the Kremlin extols national unity over historical truth.

item.title: Moscow 2016: The Prince and the Penguin
item.description: In Moscow, 2016 will go down as a complicated year. Perhaps it will be viewed as the first step toward a shiny, orderly dystopia. Or maybe it will go down in history as a year when more order (and pink penguins) were enforced on the unruly inhabitants.

item.title: Russia and the West: Enemies Are Not Forever (Op-ed)
item.description: Twenty-five years on, we are still wrestling with the consequences of the collapse of the Soviet Union. With so few grounds for optimism, we must view negative trends in relations between Russia and the West in a wider perspective.

item.title: Dining Out in Moscow: The Best of 2016
item.description: Whatever 2016 brought to Russia and the world, the year delivered at least one terrific benefit: a slew of great cafes, coffee shops, and restaurants in Moscow.

item.title: Muchnik's Picks: Kasta, Noize MC and More Music in Moscow on the New Year's Weekend
item.description: It's the New Year's Eve weekend and the great exodus from the capital has already started, just check out the traffic jams on Google maps. But if you chose to stay in Moscow for the longest weekend of the year, here are some great gigs you can go to between skating and visiting museums.

item.title: Fathers and Sons: How Trump Split Americaâ€™s Russian Immigrant Families
item.description: An increasing number of Soviet and Russian-speaking immigrants are speaking out against a president-elect the majority of their community enthusiastically supports.

item.title: Ringing Out the Year in Russian Culture
item.description: We asked some of our favorite art critics to tell us what they thought was the best of the year 2016 â€” the most positive and encouraging events or trends â€” and what was the worst â€” the most negative artistic trends or events, or simply the biggest flops.

item.title: In Search of Aleppo's Heroes (Op-ed)
item.description: Fed contradictory and distorted information, Russians became indifferent to humanitarian catastrophe in Syria. But they were not the only ones to be misled, says 2016 Pulitzer Prize laureate Sergey Ponomarev.

item.title: Why the West's Betrayal of Democratic Russia Brought Us Putin
item.description: The West betrayed not only the Russians who celebrated freedom in 1991, but also the eastern Europeans who longed for security, yet ended up feeling less secure than they did after Russiaâ€™s democratic revolution.

item.title: The West Is Burning, But Russia's Future Is Bright Indeed
item.description: It was a long and difficult year for all humanity, TV show host Dmitry Kiselyov summarized, but Russia has emerged victorious and brimming with dignity. Society is united, the economy is secure, and the military is leading a major war on terrorism.

item.title: The Time She Didnâ€™t Come Back Alive
item.description: Russia mourns the loss of its most prominent humanitarian Elizaveta Glinka, known to millions of Russians more simply â€” Doctor Liza.

item.title: We, the People: The Green Shoots of Russia's Grassroots
item.description: Political protest might be dead in Russia, but grassroots activism was very much alive in 2016. The Moscow Times reviews the most memorable cases.

item.title: Non-Combat Losses in Russia's Ill-Defined War
item.description: The victims of the crash of the Tu-154 airplane near Sochi were peaceful people â€“ performers, journalists, and even the renowned doctor. They are casualties of a war in which all Russians indirectly participate, whether they want to or not.

item.title: Moscow TV Round-Up: Ring Out the Year with Laughs
item.description: Itâ€™s Comedy Favorites Week on Moscow TV, as the capitalâ€™s small screens signal the run-up to New Yearâ€™s and the long holiday with lighthearted movie hits everybody knows, loves, quotes â€“ and enjoys watching again

item.title: Pandemonium for Putin
item.description: This year, as in years past, many people brought homemade signs, hoping a vivid or well worded banner might win them the chance to open their mouths. Others had different priorities.

item.title: Me, My Year and My Beloved Moscow (Op-ed)
item.description: Before being hospitalized with a serious condition, former Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov wrote an exclusive end-of-year op-ed for the Moscow Times. We publish it today and wish him a very swift recovery.

item.title: A Perfect Trap, And A President Re-Invented
item.description: Over the course of his presidency, Vladimir Putin has been constantly redefining himself: from Yeltsin's successor through postmodernist "managed democracy" on to open authoritarianism marked by large-scale purges within his circle.

item.title: In Name Alone: Russia's Fake Privatization
item.description: It was supposed to be a simple transaction: The government would sell shares in key state companies to private investors and fill state coffers. But there was nothing simple about it.

item.title: Russia Enters a Time of Transition, by Stealth
item.description: 2016 was the year in which Russia rediscovered politics. The media began feeding on leaks from senior officials, poorly disguised as â€œinvestigative journalism.â€ Russians can now read about the new villas, yachts, airplanes, and offshore companies that belong to the Kremlin retinue. All this dirty laundry being aired in public suggests there is now a behind-the-scenes power struggle at the top. You could call it â€œfilthy glasnost.â€ The Kremlin felt the effect of this trend in Septemberâ€™s parliamentary elections. Paradoxically, even though United Russia, the pro-Kremlin ruling party, did better than ever, the results showed that Russiaâ€™s rulers can no longer take public support for granted.

item.title: From Brekzit to Dopingovy Skandal: The Year in Words
item.description: Every year folks around the world choose the word of the year â€” that one word that encapsulates the spirit and meaning of the year gone by.

item.title: Notes on a Scandal: Jeered Russian Olympic Swimmer Reflects on her 2016
item.description: Swimmer Yulia Yefimova had a tough road to Rio after a doping scandal and testing positive for using the drug meldonium. But she made it, and won two silvers. Now she tells her story.

item.title: Live Blog: President Putin's 2016 End of Year Press Conference
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s annual press conference kicked off at noon today. A record number of journalists â€“ 1,437, both domestic and foreign â€“ are attending the event, hoping for a chance to ask Russiaâ€™s leader a question.

item.title: Welcome to Winter, People. The Russians Have Been Waiting.
item.description: The winter solstice arrived officially this week for the planetâ€™s northern hemisphere. For millions across Russia, the winter wakeup call came when the temperatures outside dropped to historic lows.

item.title: Happy New Year Moscow Style
item.description: Moscow is a great place to ring in the New Year. Trees, sweets, treats, Ded Moroz and Snegurochka, parties, concerts, and fireworks. Here are some of our suggestions for a great New Year's Eve - and one more for Christmas!

item.title: Why U.S. â€” Russia Trade Still Matters
item.description: Sectoral sanctions and countersanctions might dominate the headlines, but the local backstory is one of mutually beneficial cooperation, says U.S. Ambassador.

item.title: Russian Music Teacher Fired After Homophobe Crusader Complains About Her Piercings
item.description: Maria Shestopalova could be the 65th teacher to lose her job thanks to one manâ€™s war on â€œsocial deviantsâ€ in education.

item.title: Muchnik's Picks: Zemfira, Artemiev and More Music in Moscow on the Weekend
item.description: The forecast says this weekend there will be a bit of a thaw, so enjoy this respite from the harsh Moscow winter and use this time to go to some of the gigs we picked for you, including Zemfira and Artemiev.

item.title: The Price of War
item.description: Itâ€™s horrifying toÂ think that Ambassador Andrei Karlovâ€™s gruesome assassination was specifically designed for the worldâ€™s television screens. But, most likely, itÂ was. This was aÂ grisly routine familiar toÂ anyone who watches the news.

item.title: Moscow Student Accused of Islamic State Ties to Hear Verdict Dec. 22
item.description: On Dec. 22, Moscowâ€™s District Military Court will hand down a verdict to Varvara Karaulova, the Moscow student accused of attempting to join Islamic State.

item.title: The Aftermath: What Russia Will Do After the Assassination of Its Envoy
item.description: Russia can secure now its role as the new kingmaker in the Middle East, displacing the United States as the regionâ€™s indispensable power

item.title: Moscow Restaurants: News and Openings
item.description: Cheap coffee, great pizza and pub grub, not to mention a noodle shop pop-up that now has a home - it's a great batch of new places to keep body and soul together during the pre-holiday season.

item.title: Konchalovskyâ€™s â€œParadiseâ€ Short-Listed for Oscar Nomination
item.description: Andrei Konchalovsky's "Paradise" has been included in the so-called shortlist of nine foreign language films to compete for next year's Oscar award.

item.title: Trump Facing Down 'Coup D'Etat,' Says Russian State Media
item.description: Protesters in Ukraine were high on drugs, the U.S. is financing Russian liberals, and U.S. President-elect Donald Trump is facing a â€œcoup d'etat.â€ Or at least thatâ€™s what the Kremlin's news programs aired this week.

item.title: Moscow TV Round-Up: Itâ€™s Non-Fiction Week, With Documentaries About Heroes, Poets, Rock Stars and More
item.description: It's Cross-Cultural Documentary Week on Moscow TV, as the small screen offers excellent features on the Beatles/Rolling Stones debate, a French-Russian master artist, a Polish-Russian war hero, a Russian poet war hero, and the children of famous and infamous Third Reich Germans.

item.title: Ready Your Chopsticks at Wang & Kim
item.description: A new restaurant from the folks who brought Kitaiskiye Novosti (China News) to Moscow's Asian food lovers. This time with a twist: Korean barbecue and other dishes.

item.title: Georgia's Unexpected Daughter
item.description: Nastya Bendukidze only discovered her fatherâ€™s real identity six years before he died. Kakha Bendukidze, the great post-Soviet businessman, billionaire, reformer and philanthropist, had never even mentioned to friends or reporters that he might have had a daughter. Yet it was only in the year before he died that Nastya understood that Kakha had plans for her, and that those plans would turn her life upside down.

item.title: California's Separatist Movement Gets an â€˜Embassyâ€™ in Moscow
item.description: After a long courtship between the â€œYes California Independence Campaignâ€ and the Kremlin-funded â€œAnti-Globalization Movement of Russia,â€ the world is getting its first-ever â€œCalifornian embassy.â€

item.title: Penned In: Russian Police Go After Football Hooligans Ahead of World Cup
item.description: With 15 months to go until Russia hosts the FIFA World Cup, authorities are stepping up the pressure on violent fans.

item.title: Immersive Theatre Takes Hold in Moscow
item.description: Moscow theater, usually receptive to innovative forms, has taken a little while to catch on to immersive theater. But this season the tide has turned, with homegrown productions and visiting directors putting the genre firmly on the cultural map.

item.title: Russian Man-Hating Plants and Other Wonderful Creatures
item.description: If misogyny is hatred or prejudice against women, whatâ€™s hatred or prejudice against men? This word is much less common in English: misandry. And how do you say â€œmisandryâ€ in Russian? Simple! Ð¤ÐµÐ¼Ð¸Ð½Ð¸Ð·Ð¼ (feminism).
